sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: He took it out 〈…〉 purſe, all filled with gold, juſt before 〈…〉 in. O, if the Prince had a mind, 〈…〉 he, 〈◊〉 but a • nd! he is 〈…〉 , you 〈◊〉 know!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: But why did he give you 〈◊〉 I can't underſtand it. He muſt 〈…〉 had ſome motive.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p:
Yes, • ma, ſo he had 〈…〉 muſt know, this morning his watch di •
〈…〉 he was out hunting all day yeſterday, and 〈◊〉 had forgot to wind it up: ſo this morning 〈◊〉 look, mama, that's the place. Well, he ca • me to him, and bid me ſee what it was oc • by my watch; and as I had never a one—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: He gave you that money?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Yes; he gave it me to buy one.
Twelve guineas, mama!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Look at me and tell me,— may I believe this?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Ye • , indeed. But I am in no ſuch great hurry to have a watch, becauſe I can have one at any time.
Take it, mama; take this money, and put it in your own purſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: What, my child!—what!—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: I am ſo ſorry, mama, to ſee you always 〈…〉 . 〈◊〉 mama! I wiſh I had a 〈…〉 of money, and then you ſhould never 〈◊〉 any more! for all that I had, y •• , every 〈◊〉 of it, I ſhould give it all to you, my dear mama, with my whole heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p:
(
• ing over him.) Would you, my child?—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: What joy I ſhould have, my dear mama, to ſee you laugh, and be happy!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (embracing him.) I am ſo already, my love! I would not give up the pleaſure I feel at this moment, for all the wealth in your Prince's poſſeſſion.
O, little can you judge of the feelings excited in the heart of an unhappy mother, by the compaſſionate tenderneſs of a darling ſon!

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: (again taking her hand.) But you 〈◊〉 accept this money, at leaſt? my dear mama! I am ſure you won't refuſe me that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Yes, my love, I will take it. You may perhaps be impoſed upon by others, and therefore I will myſelf ſee—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: What, mama! to get me a watch?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: If you continue with the Prince, you will really require one.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: No, no, I ſhall not. The Prince has watches every where, and he told me himſelf I ſhould not want one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Yet he gave you this money that you might buy one?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: That does not ſignify, for he ſaid ſo, afterwards, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: You are deceiving me, my dear? and you ſhould never 〈◊〉 a • e word, not even from love to your mot • er.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p:
A falſehood! You don't believe me, then? Well, I only wiſh the Prince was here himſelf! If he would but 〈◊〉
▪ O! •• re he is!

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: THE PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, THE PAGE.

sp.speaker: THE PAGE
sp.p: IS it not true, Sir, that you gave me the twelve guineas firſt of all to buy a watch?

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (ſmiling.) Yes, my dear.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: And did not you tell me afterwards that I ſhould not want one?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: True again!

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (turning to his mother.) There, mama, there! do you hear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Your Highneſs will, I hope, forgive the ſimplicity of a child, who is ignorant of the reſpect which—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Forgive it? I am enchanted with it! and I only wiſh it were univerſal. It is Nature in its firſt beauty. Speak freely, my little friend! Your mother, then, would not believe you?

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (a little angrily.) No, Sir; ſhe would not believe me firſt; and then after that, ſhe would not take the money.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: How? ſhe would not take the money! And did you, then, ſo little value my preſent, as to wiſh to part with it? I did not expect to hear this.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Sir?—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Had I thought it, I ſhould not have felt myſelf inclined to have done much more for you. Be honeſt, however, and own the truth to me.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: (looking at his mother.) Oh, Sir!— if you did but know how poor ſhe is!

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (taking his hand.) Good-hearted little f • llow! you have ••• rificed, then, the ſole object of your own wiſhes, to give ſuccour to your mother? It would be barbarous to ſuffer an action, ſuch as that, to deprive you of your watch. Here (holding to him his own) take this! and were it the only one I poſſeſſed in the world, I would not but beſtow it as the recompence of your tenderneſs.

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (receiving it with joy.) O thank you, thank you, Sir!—But does it go?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Yes, yes, be perfectly ſatisfied; it goes extremely well.

div.stage: (The Page runs up to his mother, to ſhew her the watchboy.)

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Come, my good boy, put the watch up for the preſent. But ſince you ſo well underſtood how to employ the little money I juſt now made you maſter of, here, (giving him his purſe) take alſo this; you will find in it an hundred guineas to replace the twelve you had at firſt.

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (aſtoniſhed.) What, Sir!

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Do you heſitate? Take it, I tell you.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: What! the purſe, and all that is in it too? O no! it's too much, (offering to empty it.)

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Certainly too much, were it all deſigned for yourſelf: but I only put it into your hands to diſpoſe of it. And who can you think of, that might find it moſt uſeful?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Who might find it moſt uſeful?
sp.stage: (He looks from the Prince to his mother, and then at the Prince again.)
sp.p: Ah! take it, my dear mama!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (approaching the Prince.) Your Highneſs—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p:
I muſt entreat you, Madam, t • wave all ceremony of thanks. You will fin • but very little; and I much fear I ſhall d • a greater evil than this may do you good 〈◊〉 you muſt be ſenſible yourſelf, that • child is too young and too helpleſs to co ••• nue with
me. He is not yet of an age to be of any poſſible ſervice to others. To ſpeak, therefore, frankly, I hope you will not make any difficulty in again receiving him.—You are ſilent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Forgive me, Sir •

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What?—Speak.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Forgive me, I • ire you. —I am wrong to bluſh at a poverty I have not brought upon myſelf; and which, therefore, without any ſhame, I might openly and ſincerely confeſs • your Highneſs.

Alas, Sir! I muſt own myſelf too poor to educate, or to maintain my child! I have long looked towards the future with an aching eye: and now indeed, I will be wholly a prey to ſorrow! O, if I muſt carry back this laſt and only object of all my cares, to the ſad refuge of my own miſery—this child, as yet too young to be ſenſible of the loſs he has ſuffered— (ſhe endeavours to reſtrain her tears) in — his father! —Ah, Sir! forgive a mother's weakneſs!

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (in a voice of grief, and taking the Prince's hand.) Sir! mama is crying.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Well,—but if you go and live with her?—

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (in a tone of ſupplication.) You won't ſend me away, Sir?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p:
Shall • ot? do you then think will not? Sweet little fellow! I am delighted 〈◊〉 your confidence in me. Well, Madam, 〈…〉 ſtay.—It will, however, ſurely be a pity, 〈◊〉
•• ld his morals, his innocence—but no, there ma • be nothing perhaps to fear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (looking at him with earneſtneſs.) His innocence, Sir?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: No matter, no matter; you may perhaps imagine I wiſh to withdraw my conſent; but pray make yourſelf eaſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (fearfully.) But yet, will your Highneſs think •• e too preſumptuous ſhould I venture—Ah! Sir! may I not ſupplicate you would explain yourſelf?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: All I mean, Madam, is, that for a long time paſt, I have been ex • ly diſſatisfied with my Pages. Their ſociety and their example, therefore, may perhaps—but, however, it is nothing beyond a perhaps, and we can but try.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p:
(ſnatching her 〈…〉 with eagerneſs.)
O, no, no!

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p:
(with pretend •
〈…〉 ) No! —Well, juſt as you pleaſe, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: The innocence of • y child, is, of all things, moſt pr • ci ••• to 〈◊〉 . Ah! I ſhudder to • nd to what danger 〈…〉 him!

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: You muſt 〈…〉 —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: I can conſider nothing, Sir! I ſee my child in the mid • fla • es.—If I can but ſnatch him from th •• , what matters it that he be left naked in my arms?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But wit ••• t either money or education, what is to become of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Whatever it may pleaſe God. I reſign myſelf to his decrees! If he is not able to ſupport his birth, let him plough in the fields! O let him, ſo he preſerve but his innocence; let him die in the very boſom of poverty!

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (in his natural voice.) This, indeed, is thinking nobly: and I ſee how thoroughly you merit all that my ſituation in life can enable me to do for you.
In what can I ſerve you? Tell me, what aſſiſtance can I give you? Speak openly; aſk what you pleaſe; believe me, Madam, you have now a friend before you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (with emotion.) Ah, Sir!—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Tell me, in the firſt place, what is your ſituation at preſent? What is the condition of your eſtate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: It is utterly impoſſible for 〈◊〉 to ſave it.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Your debts, then, are conſiderable 〈…〉 , you have law-ſuits. Have 〈…〉 of 〈◊〉 them?

None, Sir. There is one 〈…〉 the ſucc •••• on, which 〈…〉 to ha ••
〈◊〉 decided in my 〈…〉 which my right is i • conteſtible; 〈…〉 riches and power! I quitted 〈…〉 a compromiſe; 〈◊〉 I 〈…〉 ſucceed.

•• joice that you could not; for you ſhall nowhere ample juſtice, without making any 〈◊〉 to obtain it. I plight my 〈◊〉 to you that this ſh • ll be done. You muſt alſo favour me with • cepting a penſion of a hundred 〈◊〉 a year. I only wiſh I could as 〈◊〉
• ir •••• t all your other difficulties.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (caſting herſelf at his feet.) Oh! Sir! your Highneſs is too, too good!—How can I ever—

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (raiſing her.) What are you doing? Riſe, riſe, Madam. I merely acquit myſelf of what I owe to the memory of the officer whoſe widow you are: and I only do for you that which I wiſh to do for every one whoſe virtues ſo deeply penetrate my heart. Tell me, do you heſitate any longer in taking back your child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, Sir, I can forget—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: And you, my lit • le friend, are you willing to return to your mother?

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (holding his watch in his hand.) To go back to mama? O yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: I know, however, that you love me: you would willingly, therefore, ſtay with me alſo?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: O very, very willingly, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But, in giving you again to your mother, I muſt part from you myſelf: and you have ſo earneſtly entreated me to keep you! —Your mother, too, has thrown you ſo wholly under my protection!—Well, I muſt try ſome other means to conciliate matters. Stay here, Madam, a little while; I ſhall be with you in a moment. (He goes out.)

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: Mrs. DERFORD, THE PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DERFORD
sp.p: O BLESSED day! O unexpected happineſs!

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Well, dear mama, well, are you quite happy now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (tenderly drawing him to her.) My child! my deareſt child!

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: But you don't ſeem to be glad, my dear mama? Why, you ought to be quite in high ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: My own felicity makes me bluſh: it reproaches me for the little confidence I have placed in Providence, and for the bitter affliction I have felt that ever I gave you birth. It was but a moment after hearing of the loſs of your father, I looked upon you with compaſſion and terror; I wept that I had brought you into the world! (She takes him in her arms, and embraces him.) Yet it was thou that wert deſtined to comfort and ſupport thy miſerable mother! and by thy own little hands were her tears to be dried! O Heaven, what can I now deſire? Nothing, nothing, but to be ſatisfied of your brother's future lot, and then my happineſs would be perfect.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: My brother's lot! What do you mean, mama?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Should the Prince know what he has done—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Why, if he did know it, he would take no notice of it. You ſee, my dear mama, how generous and good he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Yes, my love, to us, who are guilty of no fault.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Beſides, mama, he has promiſed me to keep the ſecret, and never let the Colonel hear of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (alarmed.) How! has he promiſed you that?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: He has indeed. So now you need not be frightened any more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: I am quite confounded! You have told him, then—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: O, hardly any thing, mama; only juſt what I knew. But he aſked me himſelf about my brother's behaviour, and ſo I could not tell ſtories. You know you always bid me not do that, mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: But, my love, my dear child—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Why what, mama! are you uneaſy? are you vexed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Am I uneaſy! good Heaven, am I uneaſy! Ah! ſhould the Prince enquire further,—ſhould he learn—thou mayeſt perhaps have undone thy mother, and thy brother; thou mayeſt have plunged us into a gulph of affliction and ruin!

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (ready to cry.) A gulph of affliction?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Some one is coming. (She embraces and ſoothes him) Say nothing: dry up your tears; they will but ſerve to make the evil yet more ſerious. Be quiet, be compoſed!

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE, The PRINCE, followed by Capt. DETTINGEN, and Enſign DERFORD.

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE.
sp.p: COME in, Gentlemen.
You, then, are young Derford, ſon to the brave Major!

sp.speaker: The Enſign
sp.p: (bowing very low.) Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: To me that is a great recommendation. Your father was a man of high honour, and an officer of noble courage. Doubtleſs his example has awakened your emulation, and you make it your ſtudy to render yourſelf worthy of being called his ſon?

sp.speaker: The Enſign.
sp.p: I only do my duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: And that is doing every thing. The greateſt of men cannot do more. You ſee here, Sir, your mother. Her virtues, and the fair promiſe I ſee in your amiable little brother of inheriting them, have given me the moſt advantageous idea of all your family; and it is owing to this that I have deſired to aſſemble you all before me.

sp.speaker: The Enſign
sp.p: (ſtill bowing.) Your Highneſs does me the utmoſt honour.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: I do you no more than I conclude you deſerve.

sp.speaker: The Enſign.
sp.p: Your Highneſs judges of me moſt favourably.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: In ſhort, Sir, I only wait for a fuller conviction that the judgement I am inclined to form of you, is right, in order to make your fortune. That eaſy and aſſured air, however, which ſo well becomes you—

sp.speaker: The Enſign.
sp.p: O Sir —

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p:
Beſpeaks — you muſt permit me to be explicit,—a ſoul that is either very noble, or utterly corrupt. There is no ſuſpecting the ſon who is born of ſuch parents; no, it is not poſſible. Tell me, then, Sir, what is
there I can do for you? One ſtep higher would not much advance you: what ſay you?

sp.speaker: The Enſign
sp.p: (rubbing his hands.) No, certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But if we ſhould jump over that ſtep?—A Captain's rank, and a company, ſeem always the grand aim of every young officer. But firſt, however, (turning ſuddenly to Captain Dettingen) what have you to ſay, Sir, of your nephew?

sp.speaker: Capt. Dettingen
sp.p: (confuſed.) Me, Sir! what have I to ſay of him?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: One would ſuppoſe ſome harm?

sp.speaker: Capt. Dettingen.
sp.p: No, Sir, on the contrary, much good. I think he has courage, and will make a brave —

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (looking at the Enſign with an air of ſatisfaction.) Indeed? Is this true?

sp.speaker: Capt. Dettingen.
sp.p: Beſides, he is of an exceeding good height, and figure.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Certainly; he is a very fine young man. But what are his morals? What is his conduct? I am aſhamed, indeed, to queſtion you upon ſuch trifles: yet I wiſh to know his character.

sp.speaker: Capt. Dettingen
sp.p: (ſmiling.) Why, Sir, perhaps rather too much gaiety, ſometimes—a little raſh and haſty; but then, as your Highneſs knows, that does not miſbecome a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: As I know, Sir? Upon my word, this is quite new to me! Nothing more remains, then, Madam, but that you give me your teſtimony. What do you ſay yourſelf for your ſon?—
Nothing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: What, Sir, ſhould I ſay?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What you really think of him; the truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Is that, Sir, poſſible? If he merits my praiſe, ought I to give it in his preſence? or if he deſerves my blame, ought he to receive it before the maſter of his deſtiny?

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (ſmiling.) Well parried, Madam! You join to the tenderneſs of a mother, all the addreſs of a woman. It is impoſſible not to admire you. Sir, (turning gravely to the Enſign) every body has ſome method of his own; I, alſo, have mine. When I mean to promote any officer, I begin by putting him under arreſt. What think you of this way?

sp.speaker: The Enſign
sp.p: (alarmed.) Your Highneſs—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: 'Tis my cuſtom. Give up your ſword to the Captain. Behaviour more modeſt might have made me pardon all; but this confident air, this forward aſſurance—with a conſcience ſuch as yours!—What can be hoped from a young man ſo bold and ſo unmoved, who muſt be certain he has merited my diſpleaſure, and who knows how unworthily he has treated the beſt of mothers: but who, notwithſtanding—Captain Dettingen, ſee that he is kept under arreſt for a month. I aſk no explanation of what is paſt; I am de • erred, Madam, by my eſteem for you, by the manner in which I gained my information, and yet more, by the circumſtances which make me preſume that his fault is of a very ſerious nature.
sp.stage: (In a voice of firmneſs and ſeverity:)
sp.p:
Captain Dettingen, if any thing wrong ſhould happen in future, I inſiſt upon being told of it
inſtantly. Mark me, Sir, inſtantly! My intention is to promote the young man hereafter; and neither you, Captain, nor you, Madam, muſt attempt any alteration in my plan of proceeding.
I charge you upon no account to give to him even the ſmalleſt trifle by way of preſent. His pay ought to ſatisfy him. Let him learn to limit his expences.
sp.stage: (He makes a motion to him with his hand to retire.)
sp.p: Go, Sir; and ſubmit to the puniſhment you have deſerved.

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: The PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE.

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: YOU ſeem melancholy!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford
sp.p: (reſpectfully.) Alas, Sir, am I not a mother?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But you are not one of thoſe weak mothers, who, to ſave their children from a little preſent pain, would not have t • errors corrected?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: That, indeed, would be miſtaken fondneſs. No, Sir, my ſole fear is, leſs he ſhould have loſt for ever the favour of his Prince.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: No, no, take courage, Madam. My view is merely to make him merit the ſervices I mean to do him. Youth has much claim to indulgence; and I moſt willingly, for the preſent, forgive his errors and follies; but I cannot do it always. The pardon which for once may awaken the love of virtue by repentance, if repeated, may only ſtrengthen a diſpoſition to vice. But for the reſt, be not under any uneaſineſs. The young man will be brought into the right path; and my good offices towards him ſhall keep pace with his reformation.
As to this child, what do you think are my intentions for him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: I cannot tell, Sir; but I well know they muſt be all for his happineſs and advantage. Oh, Sir! the day has never paſſed, that I have not paid the tribute of veneration to your Highneſs' virtues; but I am now firſt ſenſible how ſhort it has been of your noble deſert.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What are you ſaying? I ſee you do not know me. My deſign is but to give a brave officer to the State, and a faithful ſervant to myſelf; and to bring up a friend for my ſon, who ſhall one day be as willing to ſacrifice his life to him, as his father was to me.

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: The PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE, An ATTENDANT.

sp.speaker: THE ATTENDANT.
sp.p: PLEASE your Highneſs, the Maſter of the Royal Academy.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Bid him come in. I flatter myſelf, Madam, you will only have to hear my deſign, in order to approve it.

div.head: SCENE XVI.
div.stage: The PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE, And the MASTER.

sp.speaker: THE MASTER
sp.p: I ATTEND your Highneſs' pleaſure.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Good-morrow to you, Sir; I am glad to ſee you. Will you pleaſe to inform me what is the yearly pay for children of high rank at the Academy?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: Of high rank, Sir? why, according to circumſtances.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Pray anſwer to the point.

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: Fifty pounds, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Very well. I mean to put this child under your care. And as I i •• end to ſupply the place of a father to him, I deſire that he may have every thing that a man of the firſt condition would order for his ſon. But, pray tell me who has the charge of watching over theſe young people? for that is the moſt eſſential point in their education.

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: The aſſiſtant maſters, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p:
And, no doubt, they are equal to that employment? However, as I do not know them, it is upon you ſolely I ſhall depend. I have the greateſt confidence in you. Are you
willing to undertake, yourſelf, the care of this child's education?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: It is but my duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: I do not aſk it of you as a duty; I wiſh to know if you can conſent to it with pleaſure?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: In my duty, Sir, I always find my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Very well; you may then rely upon my gratitude.
sp.stage: (To the Page, taking him by the hand:)
sp.p: Come hither, my little friend. You ſee this gentleman? He is good and amiable. Will you go and live with him?

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (after looking a little while at the maſter) Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But underſtand, at the ſame time, in what light you are to conſider him. He will be your maſter, and your benefactor. He will be intitled to your implicit obedience, and your affectionate reſpect. And if ever he has any reaſon to be diſpleaſed with you —
O no, Sir! indeed he never ſhall!

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: You have ſeen that I can be no leſs ſevere than indulgent; the leaſt complaint, therefore—

sp.speaker: THE PAGE
sp.p: (To the maſter, taking hold of his hand.) Indeed, Sir, you ſhall never have to complain of me! only believe me.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What do you think of the boy?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: It is enough, Sir, that I receive him from the hands of your Highneſs, to make him as dear to me as my own ſon.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: He may go with you, then, immediately. You give your conſent, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Good Heaven, Sir, my conſent!—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Go, then, my boy! Walk ever in the paths of virtue and honour, and make yourſelf perfectly eaſy about every thing elſe; your wants ſhall all be fully ſupplied. But why do you look ſo ſad?

sp.speaker: THE PAGE
sp.p: (reſpectfully kiſſing his hand) Long live your Highneſs! and may you be very happy, Sir!

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (tenderly.) And you too, my young friend, my new ſon, may you, too, be happy! How grateful his little heart is already! I ſhall now, Sir, releaſe you. And do you Madam, accompany him, and ſatisfy yourſelf of what becomes of your ſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DERFORD
sp.p:
(throwing herſelf at his fe • t.) Can I, Sir, force myſelf away, without expre ••
ing—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What are you about? I do not like this!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: Permit me, Sir, to—

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (raiſing her.) No, no, riſe, Madam; I cannot bear to ſee any body in that poſture.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Derford.
sp.p: I muſt, then, obey your Highneſs, and retire. (Lifting her hands up towards Heaven.) It is to God that I muſt proſtrate myſelf, to ſupplicate him long to preſerve the life of the moſt generous of Princes and of men.

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: (graciouſly following her a few ſteps.) Adieu, Madam; and all happineſs attend you!
